content: Arima Onsen is considered one of Japan's oldest hot springs and is known for having two distinct spring qualities: "Kinsen" (gold spring) and "Ginsen" (silver spring). Kinsen is an iron-containing sodium chloride strong saline high-temperature spring; it turns reddish-brown when exposed to air due to oxidation, and has high heat-retention effects suitable for those with cold sensitivity. Ginsen is a colorless, transparent carbonate spring and radioactive spring that is mild and gentle on the skin.

Arima Onsen has two public baths: "Kin no Yu" (Gold Bath) and "Gin no Yu" (Silver Bath), where you can enjoy the hot springs on a day trip. Kin no Yu uses the reddish-brown Kinsen and is also called "Japan's Premier Divine Spring." Gin no Yu uses the colorless, transparent Ginsen and is characterized by being mild and gentle on the skin.

Multiple spring sources are scattered throughout Arima Onsen's hot spring town, and you can see hot water gushing up close while strolling. There are carbonate spring source, Gosho spring source, Gokuraku spring source, Ariake spring source, Tenjin spring source, Urami spring source, and others; Carbonate Spring Source Park is a rest spot developed near the spring source. At Taiko no Yudono-kan, you can view exhibits on the history of Arima Onsen.

section: Arima Onsen Souvenirs and Local Products
content: The most famous souvenir of Arima Onsen is "tansan senbei" (carbonate rice crackers); near Yumotosaka, long-established shops such as Mitsumori Honpo and Yunohana-do Honpo line the street. Traditional crafts include the bamboo "Arima basket" and "Arima brush." Other popular souvenirs in the hot spring town include food items like croquettes and tsukudani, as well as hot spring-related goods.

Arima Onsen's hot spring town has a variety of restaurants including soba, Western cuisine, Japanese cuisine, cafes, and sweet shops. "Tsuchiyama-jin," known for hand-made soba, is a renowned restaurant for authentic soba. Along Yumotosaka and Taiko-dori there are also cafes and sweet shops, and you can enjoy a food stroll while exploring the hot spring town. At night, some establishments offer bars for an after-dinner drink.

One of Arima Onsen's symbols is "Nene Bridge," named after Toyotomi Hideyoshi's wife Nene; nearby are a statue of Nene and a waterside plaza. Zuihouji Park is known as a famous spot for autumn foliage, and a stone go board associated with Taiko Hideyoshi remains there. Tsuzumigataki Park has a waterfall-view teahouse, and you can stroll through nature. The hot spring town has many temples and shrines including Onsen-ji Temple and Onsen Shrine (Yusen Shrine), and you can enjoy historical exploration.

section: Access and Transportation to Arima Onsen
content: Arima Onsen is served by Arima Onsen Station on the Kobe Electric Railway Arima Line; the hot spring town spreads out immediately upon exiting the station. From the Mt. Rokko side, you can also access via the Rokko-Arima Ropeway, and from Ropeway Arima Onsen Station you can head to the hot spring town. By car, Arimaguchi IC on the Hanshin Expressway Route 7 Kita-Kobe Line is the nearest; there are multiple parking lots within the hot spring town. Arima Onsen Tourist Information Center is located in the center of the hot spring town, where you can obtain tourist information and maps.

section: Arima Onsen Hot Spring Town Stroll
content: Arima Onsen's hot spring town spreads around Yumotosaka and Taiko-dori; although there are many slopes, it is compact and can be explored on foot. Yumotosaka has souvenir shops and restaurants lining the street, and you can enjoy a food stroll while walking. The steam plaza near Taiko Bridge is a rest spot during your stroll. The hot spring town also has cultural facilities such as Arima Toy Museum and Stamp Culture Museum.

Arima Onsen's hot spring town has many ryokan and hotels with a wide range of accommodations. From large facilities like Arima Grand Hotel and Hyoe Koyokaku to ryokan such as Nakanobo Zuien and Gosho-bo, accommodations of various sizes are scattered throughout the hot spring town. Gekkoen consists of two buildings: Korokan and Yugetsu Sanso.

section: Recommended Ways to Enjoy Arima Onsen
content: Recommended ways to enjoy Arima Onsen include first soaking in the reddish-brown Kinsen at the public bath "Kin no Yu" to experience the famous spring's high heat-retention effects. Next, stroll through Yumotosaka in the hot spring town and enjoy comparing the famous tansan senbei or dining at the renowned hand-made soba restaurant "Tsuchiyama-jin." For sightseeing, "Nene Bridge" named after Toyotomi Hideyoshi's wife Nene, and Zuihouji Park where you can enjoy beautiful autumn foliage are popular. Walking while touring the spring sources scattered throughout the hot spring town—such as Carbonate Spring Source and Tenjin Spring Source—is also a unique way to enjoy Arima Onsen, and you can fully enjoy it in half a day to a full day even on a day trip.

section: Arima Onsen Spring Quality and Efficacy
content: Arima Onsen's efficacy differs between Kinsen and Ginsen. Kinsen is an iron-containing sodium chloride strong saline high-temperature spring; it has very high heat-retention effects and is said to be effective for cold sensitivity, lower back pain, muscle pain, joint pain, peripheral circulatory disorders, and more. Its high salt concentration creates a thin salt film on the skin, and moisturizing effects can also be expected. Ginsen has two types: carbonate spring and radioactive spring (radium spring). Carbonate spring excels at promoting blood circulation and is said to be effective for improving hypertension and peripheral circulatory disorders. Radioactive spring is known for its hormesis effect from trace radiation, which enhances natural healing power and has efficacy for gout and rheumatism. Being able to enjoy both Kinsen and Ginsen is a feature unique to Arima Onsen.

section: Arima Onsen Efficacy and Recommended For
content: Arima Onsen offers both Kinsen and Ginsen, so it can be recommended to a wide range of people. Kinsen has high heat-retention effects and is especially suitable for those suffering from cold sensitivity or poor circulation in the extremities, and those with lower back pain, stiff shoulders, or joint pain who work mainly at a desk. It also has moisturizing effects, so it suits those concerned about dry skin. Ginsen's carbonate spring excels at promoting blood circulation and is recommended for those concerned about hypertension or wanting to improve poor circulation. Ginsen's radioactive spring (radium spring) has efficacy for gout and rheumatism and is suitable for those with these conditions seeking tōji. Ginsen is mild and gentle on the skin, so those with sensitive skin, children, and seniors can bathe with peace of mind. Locals recommend soaking in Kinsen first to warm the body thoroughly, then relaxing in Ginsen; it is an ideal hot spring destination for those wanting to heal daily stress and fatigue.
